Congress must address this in the National Defense Authorization Act without any delay to ensure our nation keeps its promise to our troops.
The already tough sacrifices our military men and women and their families make in service to our country cannot be compounded by our nation‚Äôs failure to address this environmental crisis now.
Clean drinking water is fundamental to our public health and every single person must have guaranteed access to it.

Communities across this country have been exposed to or experienced the harmful effects of these ‚Äòforever chemicals,‚Äô with the greatest impact being on our servicemembers & military families who live in the surrounding communities & on bases where PFAS chemicals were widely used.

Yesterday, I joined over 100 bipartisan Members of the U.S. House in sending a letter to the House Armed Services Committee Chairman & Ranking Member calling for the inclusion of necessary and comprehensive cleanup provisions to address harmful PFAS. https://gabbard.house.gov/news/press-releases/rep-tulsi-gabbard-calls-pfas-forever-chemical-cleanup-defense-bill

Violence only begets violence. 

More force is only going to lead to more lives lost and more devastation.

We must prioritize the safety of our community.

We can rebuild, but we cannot bring back lives.

Our anger is just.

Our anger is warranted.

And our priority right now must be protecting one another.

I am heartbroken.

Horrified at the needless death of George Floyd, another innocent black man murdered by police in our community.

Frustrated that we keep finding ourselves in this position as a city.

Angry that justice still seems out of reach.

Donald Trump‚Äôs misinformation campaigns have left death and destruction in their wake. He‚Äôs clearly targeting Section 230 because it protects private businesses' right to not have to play host to his lies.

Trump‚Äôs order is plainly illegal. After driving our country into an economic and health care disaster, Trump is desperately trying to steal for himself the power of the courts and Congress to rewrite decades of settled law around Section 230. All for the ability to spread lies.

Today Trump proved me right. I expect those companies, and every American who participates in online speech, to resist this illegal act by all possible means. Giving in to bullying by this president may be the single most unpatriotic act an American could undertake.

More than 100,000 Americans have died, but  ‚Äúthe president has focused much of his time in recent days on matters other than the coronavirus.‚Äù https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/for-a-numbers-obsessed-trump-theres-one-he-has-tried-to-ignore-100000-dead/2020/05/27/0a9c58ee-9f63-11ea-9590-1858a893bd59_story.html
If you‚Äôd like to read Section 230, you can find it here: https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/47/230

‚ÄúSection 230 should not treat Twitter and neutral internet service providers in the same way when they function so differently.‚Äù

Write a bill, but don‚Äôt pretend you‚Äôre some hero of free speech. Undermining Section 230 will embolden government regulators and harm free speech.

‚ÄúCompanies that act like publishers should be treated like publishers.‚Äù

All are treated the same under the law. The law doesn‚Äôt define anyone as a ‚Äúpublisher‚Äù in all contexts.

‚ÄúIt makes little sense to treat companies that publish their editorial comments about others‚Äô content as if they are mere distributors.‚Äù

The law doesn‚Äôt treat anyone as ‚Äúmere‚Äù anything. It‚Äôs contextual, not all or nothing.

‚ÄúTwitter‚Äôs decision to affix its own editorial content to users‚Äô posts brings into question the basis for that immunity.‚Äù

Twitter has no special immunity. You and I have the same immunity. It‚Äôs always contextual, not blanket immunity.

‚ÄúThat statute tells courts to treat Twitter like a passive distributor of third-party content.‚Äù

False. The statute is about what you do, not who you are. You‚Äôre not liable when you moderate content. You‚Äôre potentially liable when you create content. That‚Äôs true for everyone.

‚ÄúBut under Section 230, Twitter receives a special government carve-out that shields it from liability.‚Äù

False. Everyone is treated the same, including ‚Äútraditional publishers‚Äù and anyone reading this tweet or breathing.

‚ÄúTraditional publishers are liable when they mess up.‚Äù

True. So is Twitter, for any content it creates, just like ‚Äútraditional publishers.‚Äù There is no difference.

‚ÄúBut editorializing is what publishers do, like the New York Times and the Washington Post. Your company is treated very differently from publishers, as you know.‚Äù

False. If NYT and WP moderate content, they‚Äôre not liable. If Twitter creates content, it‚Äôs liable for the content.

Difficulties, however, exist as the majority of the U.S. Island agriculture operations are small, family-run farms typically isolated from other farms and supporting research organizations.
Arable land is readily available in most locations, water plentiful, and soil fertility and drainage highly conducive to a wide variety of crop production systems.

Only Alaska has a similar disparity between where their food is produced and eventually consumed, however food production is not possible in most areas of that state, while the opposite is true in Hawai‚Äòi and other U.S. Islands.

The coronavirus pandemic has brought to the forefront unique food security challenges that must be confronted by Hawai‚Äòi and the U.S. Territories, many of which are unlike those faced by the 48-contiguous states.
